awd_titl_txt: CAREER: New Models for Controlling InP Nucleation, Growth, and Luminescence using Magic-Sized Clusters and Targeted Surface Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the hallmarks of modern society has been efficiently and effectively transforming energy from one form to another, which has enabled increased human productivity and aided economic development. As technologies mature, continued progress on this front requires developing new materials with new and improved function. As a result of their emergent, size-dependent properties, nanomaterials are forecasted to significantly shape the future of next generation energy technologies. Nanomaterial function relies on the ability of scientists to access these materials with uniform and precise atomic structures. This is an enormous challenge since nanomaterials contain hundreds to thousands of atoms and even a few atoms out of place can significantly alter their function. Research conducted under this CAREER award aims to address the fundamental challenges in controlling the composition and interfaces of nanomaterials with atom-level precision. The globally-relevant nature of this research is leveraged to advance the major educational goals of this project, namely to: 1) create an undergraduate specialization in Chemistry for Energy at the University of Washington (UW), 2) develop hands-on demonstration materials and workshops on the topic of colloidal nanoscience targeted to middle and high school students in collaboration with the UW Phi Lambda Upsilon (National Chemistry Honor Society) chapter, and 3) broaden participation in chemistry at the undergraduate, graduate and professional level through work with the Chemistry Women Mentorship Network, the UW Women in Chemical Sciences, and the NSF-supported Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation program.

The scientific goal of this award is to understand how indium phosphide (InP) and related colloidal quantum dots (QDs) nucleate and grow in solution and how to rationally modify that mechanism and the properties of the resulting nanocrystals using surface chemistry. As a step toward this goal, several themes are initiated to provide the experimental context in which nucleation, growth, and photoluminescence modulation in these materials can be studied. These include: 1) testing new models of InP nucleation using isolable, structurally characterized and atomically precise magic-sized cluster intermediates; 2) understanding how surface chemistry impacts the structure and function of InP magic-sized clusters to gain access to general strategies for anisotropic shape control and doping; and 3) discovering new post-synthetic surface chemistry to turn-on and color-tune the luminescence of InP and related QDs using Lewis acid coordination chemistry. The research approach focuses primarily on the development of new hypothesis-driven synthetic methods as well as spectroscopic and theoretical characterization of the properties and electronic structure of these materials. Ongoing collaborations with experts in time-dependent electronic structure theory, X-ray crystallography, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy are leveraged to help answer fundamental structural and mechanistic questions.  The educational component addresses the need to train the next generation of scientists and engineers to solve scientific grand challenges through the development of relevant and applicable lecture materials, learning tools and demonstrations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Washington Office of Sponsored Programs

por.por_cntn:
Breaking new ground in the solution phase synthesis of complex nanoscale matter requires innovation, imagination, rigor, and tenacity. Under this CAREER award we have pioneered new chemical strategies to stitch atoms together, creating structures with superior emissive function. Focusing on the development of indium phosphide nanocrystals, we have invested time and resources into understanding the fundamental principles that govern why and how our synthetic methods work as they do. Our CAREER research has contributed unique insights that have enabled Cd-free quantum dot displays with improved color gamut, and our atomistic synthesis approach is creating new opportunities in the application of solution-processed nanomaterials in quantum information science.  

Intellectual Merit: A few of our most important findings include: (i) We discovered that cluster to quantum dot conversion occurs through asynchronous cluster dissolution using a combination of kinetic data obtained through in situ UV-Vis spectroscopy and ex situ NMR spectroscopy. (ii) We templated the growth of a previously unknown "twistane" phase of InP nanocrystals from cluster seeds. (iii) We quantified surface-exchange equilibria using a two-site, competitive Langmuir binding isotherm using the In37P20(O2CR)51 cluster as an ideally monodisperse starting scaffold for InP quantum dot interfaces. (iv) We reconciled conflicting claims that primary amines both promote and retard precursor conversion rates for InP nanocrystals by studying the reaction between amines and In37P20(O2CR)51. (v) We demonstrated the stepwise cation exchange conversion of InP clusters to Cd3P2 clusters. (vi) We discovered a new strategy to modulate the optical properties of InP quantum dots using Lewis Acid coordination.

Broader Impacts: This award has contributed to the research and training of six graduate and three undergraduate REU students. We have published 19 papers in peer-reviewed journals, including cutting edge synthesis and mechanistic investigations, in-depth review articles that coalesce principles from across our research and the field, and tutorial articles that make our methods more accessible to the general user. Work from this award has been presented at more than 100 academic institutions and conferences by me and the students funded by the project, helping to promote the science to the community as a supplement to our publications. Beyond the new science, we have contributed meaningfully to broadening participation and educational development. Over the course of this grant period, we developed the Chemistry Women Mentorship Network (ChemWMN), which has now grown into a vibrant mentoring resource including over 90 female faculty mentors and more than 200 mentees paired to date. I co-developed the infrastructure and laboratory modules for a new course, Energy Materials, Systems, and Devices (CHEM 466/566, ChemE 440/540, MSE 466/566), in collaboration with the Clean Energy Institute. We designed the lab space, acquisitioned and commissioned $1.5 million in equipment, and developed six complete laboratory modules on the topics of Batteries, Photovoltaics, Nanoparticle Synthesis, 2D Materials, Solar Photochemistry, and Grid Simulation. Human resource development. 

 


Last Modified: 11/24/2021
Modified by: Brandi Cossairt
